statement.text: Access vessel disease refers to iliac or femoral artery pathology (stenosis, calcification, tortuosity, small caliber) that complicates endograft delivery, requiring access strategies ranging from iliac angioplasty to surgical conduit placement.

explanation.intuition: Getting a large delivery system (18-24 French) through small, calcified, or tortuous iliac arteries is like threading a garden hose through a kinked, narrowed pipe - sometimes you need to widen the pipe first or find an alternate route.
explanation.key_insight: Minimum iliac diameter should be 1-2mm larger than delivery system outer diameter. Severe calcification precludes stretching. Management options escalate from balloon angioplasty through iliac stenting, surgical endarterectomy, to iliac conduit.
explanation.technical_details: Assess on CTA: minimum diameter, calcium burden, tortuosity. Compare to device IFU outer diameter (OD). Options: (1) Predilatation with balloon, (2) Endoconduit - covered stent to crack calcium and provide smooth lumen, (3) Direct iliac artery cutdown and repair, (4) Iliac conduit - 10mm Dacron graft sewn to common iliac via retroperitoneal approach. Complications include iliac rupture, dissection, limb ischemia, and access site infection.

strategies.severe_unilateral: Contralateral access with aortouniiliac device and fem-fem bypass

clinical_pearls: Never force a device through a tight iliac - rupture is catastrophic
Endoconduits allow percutaneous management of moderate iliac disease
Have iliac conduit supplies ready when borderline access
